story_clean: Three masked individuals armed with guns and a taser allegedly held up the Lay Low Tavern in Southeast Portland just around closing time early Friday. No injuries were reported, and no suspect information is available at this time.  According to Portland police officials, the three suspects entered the tavern at 6015 S.E. Powell Blvd. before 2:30 a.m. Oct. 19 and ordered the bar's patrons to get on the floor. Two of the suspects reportedly held guns while the other held a taser.  The suspects collected an undisclosed amount of cash and fled without further incident, officials said.  Officers responding to the robbery around 2:35 a.m. searched but could not locate anyone matching the suspects' descriptions.  Anyone with information that could assist this investigation should call the PPB's Robbery Detail at  503-823-0412 . (Sign up for our free daily newsletters and Breaking News Alerts for the  Portland Patch ) Additionally, tips can be sent in to Crime Stoppers of Oregon. If your tip leads to an arrest and conviction, you could be rewarded with up to $2,500.  Tips and links to informative sources can be shared anonymously through the Crime Stoppers app. To submit an anonymous tip, visit the App Store and download P3 Tips.  Tips can also be submitted online  or by calling  503-823-HELP  (4357). Image via Google Maps

Denver police announced Thursday they have made an arrest in the fatal shooting of three homeless people in Denver in August. Maurice Butler, 38, is accused of killing Nicole "Nikki" Boston, 28, Jerome "Rome" Coronado, 39, and Chris "Little Cowboy" Zamudio, 44, in a remote corner of a parking lot at 765 S. Broadway near the Interstate-25 overpass. Detectives identified Butler as a suspect, and said it appears that "at least two of the victims and Butler were known to each other." Police said it appeared the killings were not random.  Butler was arrested Aug. 13 for drug possession and a parole violation and has been held in Denver county jail since then.  Joe Montoya, DPD division chief of investigations, said the public's tips to the anonymous Crime Stoppers tippling helped identify Butler.  "The Denver Police Department thanks the community for its cooperation and tips to Crime Stoppers, which in addition to the persistence and determination of the investigating officers, helped lead to this arrest," said Montoya. Related:  Who Killed Homeless Trio? Denver Police Seek Tips Stay up-to-date with Metro Denver news with Patch! The case against a Frankfort pediatrician charged with groping women in his office was put on hold while lawyers sift through medical records. Kishor Jain, 60, was arrested in February and faces 10 counts of felony criminal sexual abuse, five counts of misdemeanor battery, and a single count of criminal sexual assault for allegedly groping five women while working at the Hedges Clinic. Jain stopped working at the clinic soon after he was hit with the charges. Before he was arrested, Jain was named in the first of what turned into four civil lawsuits alleging he groped, fondled and sexually assaulted women while working as a doctor. A fifth lawsuit accuses Jain of sexually assaulting a minor child. To make matter worse for Jain, the Illinois Department of Financial & Professional Regulation then suspended his medical license indefinitely after he refused to testify at a hearing. During a Thursday morning court appearance, Jain's attorney, Gerald Kielian, told Judge Robert Livas that evidence was still be sorted out. "Judge, we're still working on discovery," Kielian said. "There's a lot of medical records." Judge Livas set a January date for Jain to return to court. Go check out our Facebook page.

Cedar Grove police helped to apprehend a New York man accused of a spree of vehicle burglaries that targeted "unsuspecting victims from banks and high-end stores," authorities announced Friday. According to the Cedar Grove Police Department, the charges against Andres Quintero-Medoza, 32, of East Elmhurst, New York, are the result of a month-long, multi-state investigation that began on Feb. 4. On that date, Quintero-Medoza allegedly committed a midday motor vehicle burglary and theft in the parking lot of a business at 501 Little Falls Road in Cedar Grove, stealing $2,400 in cash, police said. Responding officers discovered that the suspected getaway vehicle – a silver Jeep Cherokee – was captured on video leaving the scene, authorities stated. Following up on the evidence, CGPD Detective Carolyn Lynch discovered that the victim was followed from the bank to the parking lot. Lynch was able to locate additional surveillance video from the bank and surrounding area leading to the eventual identification of the vehicle and suspect, authorities said. Further investigation revealed that the Medoza had been involved in a spree of similar incidents, police stated. According to the CGPD, Lynch shared information and worked with Rochelle Park, Livingston and Nassau County (New York) police departments. Medoza was arrested in Nassau County, New York on Feb. 27. A detainer was placed on Medoza and an extradition application is pending. Additional charges from the various jurisdiction are reputably being filed, Cedar Grove police stated Friday. CGPD Chief Joseph Cirasa commended Lynch for her "tenacious and thorough investigatory prowess." Keep updated with local public safety alerts at the Patch Verona-Cedar Grove Facebook page.   Send local news tips and correction requests to eric.kiefer@patch.com

Two men accused of stealing cash, checks and sacramental wine from a Ramona church pleaded not guilty Thursday to burglary charges. Christopher Szumski, 34, and Brandon Tye, 19, were arrested Tuesday in a traffic stop on Interstate 8 near Main Street in El Cajon, according to San Diego County sheriff's Lt. Hank Turner. During interviews with detectives, Szumski and Tye allegedly admitted breaking into St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Ramona April 14 and ransacking it. Among the losses were safes, cash, checks and sacramental wine, Turner said. The suspects also allegedly confessed to a residential burglary in San Marcos. Stolen property was found when officers searched the vehicle the two were in when they were stopped, according to Turner. Szumski and Tye are charged with two counts each of burglary at the church and one of residential burglary in connection with the San Marcos burglary. El Cajon Superior Court Judge Evan Kirvin set bail at $200,000 for Szumski, who faces 35 years to life in prison if convicted. Tye, who faces seven years and four months behind bars, was being held in lieu of $100,000 bail. A readiness conference was scheduled for May 2 at the El Cajon Courthouse. —City News Service

A Dorchester man was arrested Saturday evening on armed robbery charges for allegedly robbing and attempting to rob two Woburn businesses. Robert Bauer, 48, was arrested on two counts of armed robbery and one count of assault with intent to commit armed robbery.  Woburn Police Chief Robert Ferullo commended his officers and law enforcement agencies which assisted in the arrest.  "I want to commend Woburn Police Detectives, our neighboring police departments and the Massachusetts State Police Violent Fugitive Apprehension Section for their work on this case," Woburn Police Chief Robert Ferullo said in a statement. "I would also like to thank the public for its assistance identifying the suspect. Today we were able to take a dangerous criminal off the streets." Police say police were able to identify Bauer through video surveillance and assistance from the public. The Dorchester man is accused of attempting to rob the BP Gas Station on Washington St. on Dec. 9 and committing an armed robbery at the Speedway convenience store on Montvale Ave. on Dec. 5.  Police say Bauer is believed to be connected to robberies in Stoneham, Somerville and Lynnfield.  Bauer was arrested by Woburn Police with assistance from the Massachusetts State Police Violent Fugitive Apprehension Section, Boston Police, Stoneham Police and Somerville Police arrest at around 6 p.m. Saturday. He was booked at the Boston Police Department and then transported to the Woburn Police Department where he is being held without bail pending arraignment at Woburn District Court on Monday. Image via the Woburn Police Department

An alleged shoplifter is on the run after escaping police custody in East Harlem this weekend, police told Patch.  The slippery suspect was briefly arrested Saturday afternoon near a Duane Reade on the corner of Madison Avenue and East 102nd Street, police said. The man had allegedly been caught shoplifting from the pharmacy and was being brought in for petit larceny, police said. While police were putting the man inside a cop car, he managed to break free on outrun officers by fleeing east on East 102nd Street, police said. The man was cuffed when he broke free, police said.  The man is described as standing 5-foot-11 with a thin build and medium complexion, police told Patch. At the time of his escape the alleged shoplifter was wearing an olive green waist length jacket, green hoodie, gray sweat pants and a black V-neck shirt, police said. Anyone with information is asked to call the NYPD's Crime Stoppers Hotline at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477) or 1-888-57-PISTA (74782) for Spanish. The public can also submit their tips by logging onto the  Crime stoppers website  or by texting their tips to 274637 (CRIMES) and entering TIP577. All tips are confidential. Photo by

Sixteen suspected gang members and associates were taken into custody Friday on drug and weapons charges at the conclusion of a federal sweep of criminal groups in Chula Vista, National City and south San Diego, authorities reported. The San Diego FBI Violent Crimes Task Force Gang Group made the arrests Thursday, according to the federal investigative agency. Criminal complaints allege that the defendants have taken part in trafficking of heroin, methamphetamine and other illicit narcotics. One is also charged with a federal firearms violation, according to FBI public affairs. Four suspects who were being sought in the sweep remain outstanding, officials said. The names of the defendants, who made their initial appearances in federal court Friday, were not released. The task force consists of personnel with the National City and San Diego police departments; the county District Attorney's Office, Probation Department and Sheriff's Department; the state Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation; and the federal Bureau of Prisons and Homeland Security Investigations. Providing support during the operation were the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, and the Chula Vista Police Department, according to the FBI. – City News Service

A Bronx man who is accused of using a New Hampshire ID to try to get money from someone else's bank account faces charges in Mount Kisco.  Westchester County police arrested Howard Walker May 23 after staff at People's United Bank on South Moger Avenue alerted them to a possible fraud attempt.  Responding officers located a man who is alleged to have given bank staff a New Hampshire driver's license and a credit card in the name of another person in an effort withdraw cash from that person's account.  The 49-year-old was charged with Identity Theft 1 st Degree, two counts of Criminal Possession of a Forged Instrument 2nd Degree, Attempted Grand Larceny 4 th Degree, and two counts of Unlawful Possession of Personal Identification.  He was arraigned in Mount Kisco Justice Court and sent to the Westchester County Jail in lieu of bail.  Image via Shutterstock

PHOTO: Arrested suspect Jonathan Espino Ruiz; image courtesy of SJPD. -----  A man struck and killed in a hit-and-run collision in San Jose early Saturday morning has been identified as 59-year-old Patrick Osmar of Menlo Park, according to the Santa Clara County medical examiner's office.  Officers found Osmar on the ground at East Hedding and North 15th streets shortly after 3 a.m. when they responded to a report of a person down, police said. The victim was pronounced dead at the scene, according to police. An initial investigation showed Osmar was in the road when an eastbound car hit him and then left the scene, according to police. The suspect, later identified as Jonathan Espino Ruiz, was later found and arrested in connection with the collision, police said. Ruiz was booked into Santa Clara County Jail on suspicion of hit-and-run and other alleged crimes unrelated to the collision, according to police. The incident was the 42nd fatal collision on city streets this year, according to police. Anyone with information on the case is asked to call police Detective Kevin McMillin at (408) 277-4654. Those who wish to remain anonymous may call Silicon Valley Crime Stoppers at (408) 947-7867. — By Bay City News Service

The pastors of The Church — A Place of Worship for All Nations in Mesquite have called the assault allegations against them "completely false," the organization told Patch Saturday night  through Facebook . The Church's comment came roughly a day after Mesquite Police charged Deborah Ann Graham, 64; David Asa Graham, also known as Edward Gandy, 24; and Tonya Hill, 46, with unlawful restraint and engaging in organized criminal activity by committing an assault causing bodily injury. "We deny any wrong doing. We are positive and confident that this matter will be resolved," The Church said in its statement. "We are asking that everyone respects our right to due process instead of rushing to judgement. We are innocent in the matter. Beyond this statement we will not be making any other statements at this time." The pastors were arrested March 20, about three weeks after the incident, the Mesquite Police Department said. The pastors allegedly restrained and hit a child with an extension cord, the Dallas Morning News  reported . Deborah Graham is the church's senior pastor, David Graham is its senior associate pastor, and Hill is the executive pastor, according to the  church's website . Their names remained on the website as of Friday afternoon. "Investigators are not currently aware of any other victims," Mesquite police said in a statement. Neither Mesquite police nor the church immediately returned Patch's requests for comment Parents who suspect a child was injured at the church or by one of the pastors is asked to call the Mesquite Police Department at (972) 285-6336.

A man is facing charges after allegedly dragging a woman out of an Upper East Side Panera Bread last week before shoving her to the ground and stealing her purse. Ralph Moore, 57, entered a Panera Bread on East 86th Street on Aug. 20 and attempted to grab the purse of a 25-year-old woman waiting for her food, Police told Patch. The woman and the Moore got into a struggle, which resulted in the woman getting dragged out of the restaurant and shoved to the ground, police said. Moore then grabbed to woman's purse and fled into the subway, police said. The suspect was captured on surveillance film from the Panera Bread. Moore was arrested Wednesday afternoon and has been charged with robbery and criminal possession of stolen property, police said. Photo: NYPD

Two weeks after the body of a 76-year-old Arcadia grandmother was found in her backyard, officials arrested and charged a Pasadena man with Capital murder, burglary and robbery Tuesday.  On April 9, the body of Chyong Jen Tsai was found by a construction crew as they arrived to work in her backyard. Heber Enoc Diaz, 27, is set to be arraigned Friday in connection with killing Tsai. The murder charge includes the special circumstance allegations of murder during the commission of a robbery and murder during the commission of a burglary.  Prosecutors have yet to decide whether to seek the death penalty against Diaz, who has been held without bail since he was arrested last Friday by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies as he was leaving his home. The charges include allegations that he used a hammer, jab saw and box cutter in the commission of all but one of the crimes he's accused of committing a March 19 burglary. Tsai died from the "combined effects of multiple sharp force injuries, multiple blunt trauma and asphyxia," according to coroner's records. Her 2005 Lexus RX 300, stolen from her home on the 300 block of East Forest Avenue, was recovered last Thursday night in the 900 block of Colorado Boulevard. Investigators arrested Diaz the following morning, as he was leaving his home, authorities disclosed.  According to Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Marvin Crowder, though the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors approved  a $20,000 reward  one week after Tsai's Death, officers located Diaz without community help and that money remains unclaimed. Police in Garland are looking for a man they allege sexually assaulted a teenage girl on July 18. According to a statement form police, the girl was walking behind businesses in the 1300 block of Northwest Highway around 10:30 a.m. when a black car drove in her direction. The car backed into a parking space next to a dumpster bay, threatened the girl with a gun and sexually assaulted her. Police said the car appears to be a black 2013 Hyundai Elantra. The girl's attacker is described as a black male standing between 5-foot-4 and 5-foot-6 in height. He is described as having a skinny build, short haircut and a full stubble beard and was reportedly wearing a faded black tee-shirt, black pants and black boots. Anyone with information about the assault is asked to call Garland Police Department at 972-485-4840. Tips can be submitted anonymously to Garland Crime Stoppers at 972-272-8477 or online at garlandcrimestoppers.org. ( Subscribe to your local Texas Patch  for real-time news alerts and informative newsletters delivered straight to your inbox.) A reward of up to $5,000 is offered for information leading to the arrest of the suspect. Follow Dallas Patch on Facebook   Image via Garland Police Department

A cab driver was arrested after he allegedly groped a 24-year-old woman who had hailed a ride in his cab over the weekend in the River North neighborhood, according to Chicago police. Murasbek Elchiev, 27, of Niles, is charged with felony aggravated criminal sexual abuse, felony aggravated kidnapping and felony unlawful restraint stemming from the incident. According to police, the woman hailed Elchiev's cab at around 2:35 a.m. Saturday, March 3, in the 300 block of West Ontario Street. The cabbie then allegedly locked the cab's doors during the ride, and he's then accused of grabbing the woman, police said. Eventually, the woman escaped from the cab, and police said she was not hurt in the incident. Officers later arrested Elchiev at about 3:18 p.m. Saturday at a parking lot at O'Hare International Airport. His next court date is set for Tuesday. RELATED:  Taxi Driver Accused Of Sexually Assaulting Woman On North Side Elchiev is the second Chicago cab driver facing sexual abuse and kidnapping charges stemming from a woman's accusations following a fare last week, according to police. Mustafa Dikbas, 36,  was arrested  after he allegedly sexually assaulted a 26-year-old woman in his cab Feb. 25 in the 3800 block of North Recreation Drive along the city's lakefront, near Boystown, police said. Murasbek Elchiev, 27 (Photo via Chicago Police Department)

A  Bethlehem  man is accused of bringing a 14-year-old girl and a 15-year-old girl to his home where he plied them with drinks and had sex with them, according to a criminal complaint filed by city police Thursday. Bradley Larry Parker, 21, of 1849 Barbara St., was charged with statutory rape and corruption of minors and was committed to Northampton County Prison in lieu of $100,000 bail. According to the complaint, the incident happened in late August. Parker allegedly went to the Bushkill Township home of the 14-year-old where he picked both her and her 15-year-old friend up and took them to Bethlehem. It is not clear from the complaint how Parker knew the two teen-age girls. The complaint alleges that after they all went to Parker's home, he served the two girls alcoholic beverages and asked them both to have sex with him, which they did. The girls reported the incident to Upper Nazareth police on Oct. 21, the arrest affidavit says. Two days after that, the complaint says, Bethlehem Police Det. Bradford Jones interviewed Parker, who admitted the story and to knowing that the girls involved were 14 and 15. In all, Parker is facing six counts: two counts of statutory sexual assault, a second-class felony; two third-class felony counts of corruption of minors, and two misdemeanor counts of corruption of minors.

A Yorktown man was accused of violating an order of protection. Yorktown police said Thomas Maletto, 52, of Yorktown, was charged with two counts of second-degree criminal contempt, misdemeanors. The Yorktown Police Department received a report Sept. 12 about a violation of a temporary order of protection. An investigation alleges Maletto emailed the person who was under the protection order. Maletto was contacted by police and surrendered himself at police headquarters Oct. 8 where he was arrested and charged. He was arraigned and released on his own recognizance and is due back in Yorktown Justice Court Nov. 1. Get Patch's daily newsletters and news alerts right in your inbox.   Find and "Like" Hudson Valley Patches' Facebook Pages . Image via Shutterstock.

ENCINITAS, CA: Authorities sought the public's help Wednesday to identify and locate a man allegedly responsible for breaking into two cars, taking credit cards and then attempting to use the stolen cards. According to San Diego County Crime Stoppers and investigators from the North Coastal Sheriff's Station, the first vehicle burglary happened between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. Friday in the 17000 block of Avenida Alondra in Rancho Santa Fe. A gym bag with two credit cards in it was allegedly taken from a car that was locked but had the passenger window slightly open. A few hours later, just after 4 p.m., authorities said, a car was seen in surveillance video parking next to another car in front of Encinitas Country Day School in the 3300 block of Manchester Avenue in Encinitas. The window of the victim's car was open. A purse with a credit card and cash was allegedly taken. Later in the day, the man allegedly tried to use the credit cards at a business in the 1500 block of Encinitas Boulevard. Some of the transactions were canceled; some went through, authorities said.  The suspect was described as a 30- to 40‐year‐old white man between 5 feet 9 and 5 feet 11 inches tall and weighing between 140 and 160 pounds. He has a shaved head, a tan complexion and a thin build and was driving a four‐door, faded black Toyota Camry.  Anyone who recognizes the suspect or has other information about the case was urged to call the North Coastal Sheriff's Station at 760-966‐3500 or the Crime Stoppers anonymous tip line at 888-580‐8477. Crime Stoppers is offering up to a $1,000 reward to anyone with information that leads to an arrest in this case. Anonymous email and text messages can be sent in via  Sdcrimestoppers.org .

Police in South San Francisco on Thursday arrested a suspect in a series of wallet thefts targeting elderly victims.  Renetha Thomas, 42, of San Jose, was arrested on suspicion of elder abuse, burglary, credit card fraud and identity theft, according to the South San Francisco Police Department.  Detectives from the South San Francisco Police Department arrested her at her San Jose home.  Police said the arrest came after several months of investigating a series of wallet thefts in South San Francisco and in other cities in San Mateo County. Thomas would make contact with the victims at grocery stores, distract the victims and remove the victims' wallets from their purses, police said. Thomas is also accused of using the victims' credit cards to make purchases at department and convenience stores in San Mateo County, police said. Police said Thomas is responsible for at least 15 similar crimes dating back to August of 2016. ALSO SEE:  --Bay City News/Shutterstock image

A man who allegedly helped himself to a bag full of hair-care products without paying, and then threatened to harm the CVS employee who tried to stop him, has been arrested after he was recognized from surveillance video, authorities say. Montgomery County Police have charged Derrick Austin Bacon, 41, of the 3400 block of Castleleigh Road in Beltsville, for the  July 24 robbery of the CVS Pharmacy at 12209 Veirs Mill Road in Wheaton. About 10 a.m. on July 24, the suspect entered the CVS pharmacy carrying a duffle bag and went to the store's hair-care products display. A store employee reportedly saw Bacon stuff hair coloring and shampoo products inside his duffel bag. When the employee attempted to stop the shoplifter from leaving the store with the stolen merchandise, the suspect threatened to harm the employee, police say. The suspect was last seen fleeing on foot on Veirs Mill Road. Investigators posted a  surveillance video of the suspect  on Sept. 8 and asked for the public's help in identifying him. A Montgomery County Police officer recognized Bacon and identified him as the suspect in the video. Detectives obtained an arrest warrant for Bacon and arrested him at his home on Oct. 27. Bacon was taken to the Central Processing Unit, where he was charged with armed robbery, first-degree assault, and theft. Bacon was released after posting a $5,000 bond. Anyone with information about the robbery is asked to call police at 240-773-5070. To remain anonymous, call Crime Solvers of Montgomery County toll-free at 1-866-411-TIPS (8477). Crime Solvers will pay a cash reward of up to $10,000 for information provided to them that leads to an arrest in this case. »Image of Derrick Bacon, courtesy of Montgomery County Police

UPDATE: The FBI Atlanta Field office said Frank Douglas was arrested Dec. 12 in Greenville, South Carolina. ATHENS, GA -- The FBI Atlanta Field Office is asking the public to help agents locate a bank robber accused of targeting businesses in Athens as well as Conyers. Frank Douglas, 58, is charged with robbing a bank Nov. 28 in North Augusta, South Carolina.  Douglas, who the FBI says has multiple aliases, was released from the U.S. Bureau of Prisons Sept. 29, and is believed to be the suspect in a robbery reported in Athens and another in Conyers.  The first was reported around 12:11 p.m. Nov. 30 at BB&T at 1887 Ga. 20 SE in Conyers. The suspect presented a demand note to the teller, and left the bank with an undisclosed amount of money. Around 2:32 p.m. Dec. 5, the suspect walked into Bank of America at 1070 Gaines School Road in Athens, passed a demand note to the employee and left the business with an undisclosed amount of currency, the FBI added.  "During both incidents, the suspect alleged he had a gun and threatened to shoot bank employees if they did not comply with his demands," the FBI added. "Although the suspect has not presented a weapon during these incidents, law enforcement considers him to be armed and dangerous." Douglas is described as a black male who is roughly 5'10'' tall and weighs around 175 pounds. He has black hair and brown eyes. The FBI state the suspect is known to stay at budget hotels and motels near interstates under various aliases. Agents also believe he frequents homeless shelters.  Anyone with information can call Athens-Clarke County police at 706-613- 3330, Conyers Police at 770-483-6600 or the FBI at 770-216-3000. Images via FBI Atlanta Field Office

A teacher, who also coaches a female youth hockey team, was behind bars today on suspicion of sexting a girl in South Orange County. Mark Falkowski of Long Beach, 38, who is a teacher at Magnolia Science Academy No. 3 in Carson, also coaches a female youth hockey team based in the Long Beach area, so investigators are concerned there might be more alleged victims, according to Orange County sheriff's Lt. Jeff Hallock. He added that the team draws members from throughout the Southland. Investigators did not want to release the name of the team. So far, Falkowski is not accused of molesting the girl, whose age was not released, but the investigation is ongoing, Hallock said. Falkowski is accused of sending sexually charged text and email messages to the girl beginning in early 2014. He was also accused of having inappropriate conversations via Skype. Falkowski was arrested Thursday afternoon after classes, Hallock said. The alleged inappropriate relationship began while the victim was living in south Orange County and continued when she moved out of state, Hallock said. Falkowski was being held in lieu of $100,000 bail. Anyone with information was asked to call investigators at (714) 647- 7060 or (714) 647-7000. Anonymous tips may be made through Orange County Crime Stoppers at (855) TIP-OCCS. City News Service

Three offenders have been arrested after they allegedly committed a series of armed robberies around Lake View this weekend, according to  Crime in Wrigleyville and Boystown . The suspects reportedly also robbed two men near Clark and Aldine. They were fleeing from this robbery when they were arrested on Stratford Pl. around midnight on Sunday.  The offenders reportedly robbed a man at gunpoint on the 400 block of Barry St. before midnight,  Crime in Wrigleyville and Boystown  states. Officers were able to track his stolen iPhone to a vehicle driving on Newport St. toward Halsted. Officers were able to catch up with the offenders — who have not yet been named — where the three were arrested. Objects from the three robberies were found in the suspects' vehicle, as well as two handgun-style pellet guns.  For more news on crime around Lake View, 'like' Patch on  Facebook  and sign up for our free daily newsletter  here .

A shoplifting suspect who pulled a knife on the manager of a Rite Aid here - and who is a suspect in other area crimes - was arrested recently.  Woodinville Police say that the suspect shoplifted from the Rite Aid here on Oct. 19. As the suspect tried to walk out of the store with a basket full of goods, police say, the manager tried to stop him. The suspect pulled out a knife and held it at his side, so the manager backed off. The suspect then fled in a vehicle with the stolen goods, police allege.  The suspect apparently committed similar crimes in Bothell and Bellevue. He was arrested by sheriff's deputies and Bellevue Police when he appeared at King County District Court on a different charge.  Image via Shutterstock
