Mount Kisco Police Officer James Whalen was arrested, police Lt. Patrick O'Reilly confirmed. The arrest was initially reported Monday by  The Journal News .  Whalen, according to information from police and in the newspaper's report, is accused of striking a woman in her face with a closed fist and leaving her with injuries including bruising and swelling. He is also accused of repeatedly striking a man in his face with a closed fist and leaving him with swelling. Additionally, Whalen is alleged to have harmed the women in the presence of her daughter, 2, while she was seated in a vehicle. Whalen's charges, according to police and the report, include third-degree assault, third-degree attempted assault and endangering the welfare of a child, which are all misdemeanors.  The events are alleged to have taken place Thursday at around 7:20 p.m. and in front of a location on Carpenter Avenue in Mount Kisco. Whalen was arraigned on Friday, released on his own recognizance and suspended without pay, according to O'Reilly.  The criminal aspect is being handled by Westchester County police, while the Mount Kisco Police Department has oversight regarding his personnel status. Whalen surrendered to county police on Friday, O'Reilly stated. O'Reilly referred further inquiry to the county level. County police officials who were contacted could not be reached for this story.

Jamal Calloway, a 21-year-old Powder Springs man, is accused of robbing a Dacula Chevron on Sunday. Calloway is charged with armed robbery, second-degree forgery and criminal attempt to commit a crime. He is being held at the Gwinnett County Detention Center without bond. According to police, the suspect entered the gas station shortly after 3 p.m. with a mask on and demanded money from the clerk. The suspect was reportedly armed with a black handgun and ordered the clerk to place the money in a see-through bag. The suspect allegedly asked for all the $100 bills saying, "I'm gonna shoot you if you don't give me all of it. You're going to die for just this little bit." After the clerk filled the bag, the suspect ran out of the store, crossed the street and left the scene in a burgundy-colored car. A customer pulled into the parking lot as the suspect was leaving. After the clerk informed the customer about the robbery, the customer left to follow the suspect's vehicle. By the time police arrived at the Chevron, the customer had called 911 and advised he was still following the suspect. The customer provided police with a tag number and said the suspect had pulled into the Longhorn's at the Mall of Georgia. Officers arrived at the scene and took Calloway into custody. Surveillance video showed a masked suspect enter the store and point a pistol at the clerk. The video also showed the suspect leaving the store after the clerk filled the bag with money.

Police said a Ledyard man was arrested last week after he allegedly broke a window with his hand and aimed an airsoft gun at an officer. The incident occurred Wednesday approximately just before 5 p.m. at a Ledyard home. Police the accused had gone to the property against a valid order of protection, where he released the parking brake of the victim's vehicle, causing it to go down the driveway and strike another vehicle. Police said the accused also broke a window to a shed with his hand, according to a release. When officers arrived, the accused allegedly aimed an air soft pistol with the orange tip removed at an officer, police said. Police said Duncan E. Kennedy, 32, of Ledyard was arrested on charges of Breach of Peace, Criminal Mischief, Threatening, Brandishing a Facsimile Firearm and Violation of a Protective Order. Photo credit: Shutterstock

The Baltimore County Police Department is asking for help identifying a man accused of stealing from two Royal Farms stores and attempting to rob a third. In the most recent incident, on April 27, police said that a man stole four cartons of Newport cigarettes from the Royal Farms in the 6000 block of Falls Road by reaching over the counter. On March 15, he allegedly asked for six cartons of Newports at the Royal Farms in the 1500 block of East Joppa Road and after saying he did not have identification, police reported the man left the store; when the clerk walked away from the register, the man allegedly ran back in, went behind the counter and grabbed the cigarettes. On March 8, police said a customer helped avoid a robbery at the Royal Farms in the 7200 block of York Road. A man had gone to the register with merchandise and asked for four cartons of Newport cigarettes, then told the clerk: "I need you to kick it out," when officials said a customer yelled at the suspect, who ran out the door and left in a silver minivan. Anyone with information is asked to contact the  Baltimore County Police Department  at 410-307-2020 or Metro Crime Stoppers at 1-866-7LOCKUP.

Pierce County deputies this week arrested a man suspected of robbing a woman and stabbing a man at the Emerald Queen Casino in Fife. Karl Brownell was caught in University Place in a stolen car, according to police.  Brownell allegedly stole money from a woman in a wheelchair at the casino. Another casino patron, Richard Pederson, witnessed the robbery and decided to confront Brownell, according to Crime Stoppers of Tacoma-Pierce County. Brownell allegedly stabbed Pederson, who survived but was seriously wounded.  Following up on Crime Stoppers tips, deputies spotted Brownell getting into a car with a woman in University Place. He was taken into custody on charges of second-degree assault and third-degree theft, according to Crime Stoppers.  Image via Shutterstock

Three 17-year-old boys been arrested and charged in connection to an incident in which the suspects allegedly waved two guns at a construction crew in Sandy Springs. Sandy Springs police arrested Kelly Skinner, Orlando Valree and Harold Mitchell just before 1 p.m. Thursday, Aug. 11. According to the agency's  Facebook page , the trio, all students at Riverwood International Charter School, allegedly waved the guns at the crew on Raider Drive and Powers Ferry Road "several times" when they drove past the site. The teens, the agency added, are also accused of firing two shots at or near a complainant during a separate incident on River Edge Parkway. Patrol officers spotted the vehicle matching the description provided during a lookout alert and the occupants a short distance from the location of the incident. Two guns were also recovered from a car, a Honda, they were occupying at the time. According to an incident report released by Sandy Springs police, all three teens were charged with violating the city's disorderly conduct ordinance.  Image via Sandy Springs Police Department

An Alpharetta woman is out on bond following an apparent road rage incident that left an SUV's passenger side door riddled with scratches. Roswell police on Saturday, Jan. 17 arrested Letty Amelia Bradford and charged her with criminal damage to property in the second degree and disrupting public school.  Roswell police on Dec. 19 were called to Hillside Elementary School at 9250 Scott Road in reference to a woman whose black 2014 Kia Sorento had been vandalized in school's parking lot. The victim pulled into the parking lot at the school during a Christmas program and was "stuck behind the suspect for over a minute," Roswell police spokesperson Lisa Holland said.  "When the suspect didn't move, she (the victim) went around her and parked in a parking space," Holland added.  When that occurred, the suspect allegedly "jumped out of her car" and began to yell at the woman for "taking her parking space," Holland said.  After the confrontation, Holland said the suspect parked her vehicle, came back to the Kia Sorento and scratched its passenger side door. "This was a road rage incident in a parking lot that went a little too far," Holland stated.  There was over $600 worth of damage to the vehicle, which Holland said makes the charge a felony, as Georgia law classifies property damage over $500 as a felony. Bradford posted a $5,000 bond and was released on Monday from the Fulton County Jail. Photo credits: Roswell Police Department

A 40-year-old Agoura Hills man is facing charges of making criminal threats against the Islamic Center of Southern California, Los Angeles police announced Tuesday. Mark Lucian Feigin allegedly called the mosque on Sept. 20 and threatened to kill a staff member, said Cmdr. Horace Frank, of the LAPD's Counter Terrorism and Special Operations Bureau. Police serving a search warrant on Feigin's home found a large cache of weapons -- some registered to the defendant -- plus thousands of rounds of ammunition and an illegally modified clip, Frank said. The suspect, who was arrested Wednesday, was charged by the state Attorney General's Office with a felony count of terrorist threats and a misdemeanor charge of placing annoying telephone calls. He posted $75,000 bail last week and was released, the officer said. Feigin is due to be arraigned in downtown Los Angeles on Nov. 10. Frank said Feigin "crossed the line" into illegal activity when he allegedly threatened the Islamic Center staffer. "We recognize everyone has the right to free speech, but with that right comes enormous responsibility," Frank told reporters. "When someone starts talking about, `I'll kill you,' it becomes a concern to us." City News Service; Photo courtesy of the LAPD

Canton police say they have arrested the suspect wanted in connection to a bank robbery reported earlier this month.  Canton resident John S. Adams, 59, was taken into custody without incident and has been transported to the Cherokee County Adult Detention Center, Canton police said Wednesday. He's charged with robbery by force or sudden snatch in connection to the Sept. 6 incident. Officer on Sept. 20 received information that allegedly tied Adams to the robbery, which occurred at BB&T at 152 Prominence Point Parkway. Police say the suspect walked into the bank around 10:52 a.m. and made a demand for money.  No weapon was brandished, and the suspect left with an undisclosed amount of money in a light-blue older model Ford Thunderbird or Mercury Cougar. Along with the tip, the agency's Uniform Patrol and Criminal Investigations divisions were able to "obtain further incriminating information that was verified to identify and arrest the suspect," the police department said. Adams remains at the facility with a $19,769 bond.  --- Image via Cherokee Sheriff's Office

Los Angeles police detectives are asking for help finding a man wanted in connection with a con/burglary operation and targeting doughnut shops and other small businesses in the San Fernando Valley. Victor Perry Guy, 51, is one of three men suspected of committing 15 commercial burglaries. The trio allegedly posed as lottery officials on service calls in order to gain access to lottery tickets. The crimes took place between Aug. 12 and Sept. 21, according to the Los Angeles Police Department. "The suspects would portray themselves as California State Lottery employees by using fraudulent identification and uniforms," according to a police statement. "The suspects would enter the business with play slips and (lottery) stamped receipt rolls. The suspects would tell the employees they were there to service the terminals." One suspect would distract an employee while another would got to the lottery terminal and print several hundred, and sometimes even thousands, of Hot Spot lottery game tickets before leaving with the tickets, police said. Two of three suspects have been identified by detectives and one of them, John Gerry Adams, was taken into custody on Sept. 26, police said. An arrest warrant has been issued for 51-year-old Victor Perry Guy, according to the LAPD. He is white, about 5 feet 11 inches tall and 220 pounds, with black-and-gray hair. Anyone with information regarding his whereabouts is urged to call police at (213) 486-6940. After-hours and weekend calls should be directed to (877) LAPD-24-7. Anonymous tips can be submitted through Crime Stoppers by calling (800) 222-TIPS City News Service and Patch staffer Paige Austin contributed to this report. Photo courtesy of the Los Angeles Police Department.

An East Windsor man was arrested early Wednesday morning after he allegedly poured gasoline on a Manchester house and attempted to light it on fire. Zachary Reddick, 24, of 6 First Street, was charged with first-degree criminal attempt to commit arson, four counts of first-degree reckless endangerment and third-degree criminal mischief. He is being held on $200,000 bond, and is scheduled to appear in Manchester Superior Court Thursday. In a written statement, Manchester Police Capt. Christopher Davis said officers were dispatched to 76 Devon Drive around 12:30 a.m. upon a report that an individual was seen pouring gasoline onto the residence before attempting to light it on fire.  The fire did not ignite, and the suspect then walked away, Davis said. Four people were inside the house at the time; there were no reported injuries, Davis said. Through investigation, police identified Reddick as the suspect, and arrested him without incident at his home, Davis said. "At this point, the motive appears to be related to an earlier theft from the suspect while attending a get together at the victim's residence," Davis wrote.  Photo courtesy of Manchester Police Department

The FBI announces the arrest of Robert Maurice Carlisle, aka "Different, of Lithonia. Carlisle was taken into custody on a federal warrant for unlawful flight to avoid prosecution as a result of a tip from the public. He was wanted by the Gwinnett County Police Department on state warrants for two counts of Concealing the Death of Another, two counts of murder, and two counts of participating in criminal gang activity. Carlisle, 32, was arrested by the FBI's SWAT team with assistance from the DeKalb County Police Department at a residence in Stone Mountain, GA on the evening of Thursday, May 16, 2019. He was wanted in connection with the deaths of Derrick D. Ruff, 25 and Joshua L. Jackson, 25. Their bodies were found inside a storage unit at the Extra Space Storage located at 2040 Lawrenceville Highway in unincorporated Lawrenceville on Sunday, March 17, 2019. Both victims died from gunshot wounds. Ruff and Jackson were reported missing to the Athens-Clarke County PoliceDepartment last December. SEE ALSO:  New Suspect Named In Storage Space Double Homicide: Police 2 Gunshot-Riddled Bodies Found In Extra Space Storage Unit Carlisle is currently being held at the Gwinnett County jail. Further questions about the case should be directed to the Gwinnett County Police Department.  The FBI thanked the news media and the billboard campaign by the Outdoor Advertising Association of Georgia for their assistance as the tip that led to Carlisle's arrest was a direct result of the fugitive publicity they provided. The public should be reminded that the above are merely allegations and that all persons are to be considered innocent until proven guilty in a court of law.

At 11:52 p.m. Sunday Jan. 12, a concerned caller reported a hit and run in the 3000 block of Eminencia del Norte. The caller said a group of unknown people in a vehicle with no plates had driven over a main water line. Deputies arrived to the scene and discovered the group had deliberately run over five water valves in an act of deliberate vandalism. Orange County firefighters shut off the water to prevent further loss. Deputies located the vandals and arrested a 22-year-old man, who has since been released after his bond was posted. Also: At 10:19 a.m. Sunday Jan. 12, a caller reported a drunken driver in the 100 block of Avenida La Pata. A  man who smelled like alcohol got into his car and drove away. At 2:39 p.m. Sunday Jan. 12, deputies received a call about a theft in the 900 block of Avenida Pico.  Two men had stolen a box of shotgun shells from a local WalMart  15 minutes before the call was made. The caller said the thieves were both men in their early 20s but could not provide further details about the alleged suspects. At 5:06 p.m. Sunday Jan. 12, someone reported a disturbance in the 3100 block of Avenida del Presidente.  Five men were smashing trashcans, skateboarding and throwing beer cans near a local building. These are selected reports from the San Clemente Police Dispatch Services log throughout the past few days. The calls represent what was told to a sheriff's deputy in the field by the radio dispatcher. No presumption of criminal guilt or affiliation should be drawn from the information provided.

Bail was increased for a man accused of headbutting police officers during a Bush concert at the  Hollywood Casino Amphitheater  in Tinley Park. Rory Helgoth, 29, of Merrillville, Ind., appeared before Cook County Judge John Mahoney on three felony charges of aggravated battery to a police officer. Helgoth is also charged with criminal damage to property. The prosecutor said that a private security officer asked Helgoth to show his tickets Sept. 6 at the Bush concert to make sure Helgoth was in the right section. Helgoth allegedly slapped the security officer with his wallet. He was taken to the office. While Helgoth was being questioned in the office, where the prosecutor said Helgoth headbutted a security officer in the face.  Tinley Park police arrived and placed Helgoth under arrest. The prosecutor said Helgoth was handcuffed and refused to get into the patrol car, when he headbutted a police officer. Helgoth is also accused of denting the side of the patrol car.  Helgoth appeared Sept. 7 for a bond hearing at the Leighton Criminal Courts Building, where bail was set at $10,000. The assistant public defender told the judge that Helgoth did not evade his scheduled court appearance in Bridgeview.  "He hasn't picked up any new cases since his arrest," the assistant public defender said. "We can't have people fighting police at concerts, venues or in the streets," Mahoney said. The judge increased Helgoth's bail to $250,000. Helgoth is due back in court Oct. 4. On the way out of the courtroom, Helgoth shouted, "the cop got hit in shoulder, dude, not in the head."

A 37-year-old man has been charged with robbing Chemical Bank in Grafton on Feb. 23. Matthew J. Kroffke allegedly used a gun to rob the bank before escaping in an SUV.  The robbery took place a little before 11 a.m. on Feb. 23. The FBI said at the time that an unidentified white man came into the bank brandishing a black handgun. He shouted for everyone to show him their hands. He then went to the bank manager's office, pointed his gun at her and told her to get out of her office. She followed him into the lobby of the bank. The man then told the three tellers at the bank to give him large bills. The suspect paced in front of the counter and counted backwards from 30. As he counted, he allegedly pointed his gun in the faces of the tellers and threatened to shoot them. The tellers handed over the cash and no one was hurt. The man then ran out of the bank and got into a blue Ford SUV and drove off. The suspected SUV was actually stopped by Grafton Police, but officers didn't yet have all the details related to the robbery. The driver of the car was identified as Kroffke, but he was released. That traffic stop was later brought to the attention of the FBI. The FBI arrested Kroffke in the Toledo-area on Feb. 28. The Department of Justice has now indicted Kroffke for the crime.  Kroffke is from Medina County.  Photo from Shutterstock

Three men have been arrested on suspicion of sexual crimes involving a 17-year-old boy after investigators allegedly obtained digital evidence from the victim's cellphone, Sausalito police announced Thursday.   The teenager's parents reportedly contacted police after man unknown to them had mailed the victim a teddy bear as a birthday present, police said. Investigators say that led them to Douglas Stevens of Jacksonville, Florida.  Stevens and the victim, who was 16 at the time, had allegedly exchanged videos of themselves masturbating and discussed meeting in Sausalito at a future date, according to police.  Information from the victim's cellphone was also used to identify two California residents, Kenneth Pierce of Sacramento and Jason Carbone of San Diego, as additional suspects, police said. Investigators say that explicit photos and videos had allegedly been exchanged between Carbone and the victim, police said.   Pierce and the victim also allegedly took photos and videos of themselves engaging in sex acts somewhere in Marin County, according to police. Pierce is a registered sex offender in Sacramento, police said.  The teen allegedly met the suspects on the social networking applications Kik and Instagram, police said.   All three suspects were arrested on suspicion of crimes related to lewd or sexual acts with a child and for possession of child pornography, according to police.   Pierce was arrested at his home in Sacramento on June 27 and is currently in custody at the Marin County Jail, police said.   Carbone was arrested in San Diego on June 27 and was subsequently released on bail, police said.Stevens was arrested in Florida and is awaiting extradition to Marin County, according to police. --Bay City News/Shutterstock image

The preliminary exam for a suspected robber from Chesterfield Township is scheduled Wednesday morning in New Baltimore. Marvin Lee Hopkins, 62, is charged with one count of armed robbery for the Sept. 27 holdup in the Kohl's parking lot off Gratiot near 23 Mile. Hopkins allegedly grabbed a 55-year-old female shopper by the arm as she put merchandise in her trunk. He is accused of threatening to kill her if she didn't hand over her purse while implying he had a weapon. The suspect then fled on foot, deploying multiple police officers and detectives to the area. Hopkins was arrested less than a week later following tips leading township authorities to a pair who found the discarded purse and then, ultimately, to Hopkins. He had been staying at the Chesterfield Motor Inn nearby the shopping plaza where the crime took place. Hopkins, a registered sex offender, has a record dating back to 1968 when he was convicted of assault with intent to rob while armed. He was then convicted of second-degree criminal sexual conduct in July 2010 in Macomb County, according to the Michigan Department of Corrections database. The preliminary exam is scheduled for 9 a.m. Wednesday in 42-2 District Court, according to court officials. Check back with  Patch  for updates on this story.

A Milwaukee man is facing charges after he was caught allegedly carrying  Suboxone  strips in his wallet while being suspected of shoplifting at . Ryan J. Mueller, 21, was charged in Milwaukee County Circuit Court Tuesday with one count of possession of a controlled substance. If convicted, he faces up to 30 days in jail and $500 in fines. According to the criminal complaint: On Feb. 28, Greendale police were called to  after an employee accused Mueller for being involved with a shoplifting incident at the store. He was arrested and an officer found implements used to steal from retailers along with eight plastic baggies in his wallet each containing strips similar to  Listerine strips . The officer then took the strips to a nearby Walgreens and the pharmacist identified the strips as Suboxone. Mueller admitted the drugs were his and that he didn't have a prescription for them. He will make his initial appearance in court March 16.

IMPERIAL BEACH, CA: A 20-year-old tutor at Mar Vista High School in Imperial Beach charged with having unlawful sex with an underage male student must stand trial on four felony charges, a Chula Vista judge ruled Thursday. Alejandro Rodriguez faces up to five years in prison if convicted. Rodriguez was arrested March 9 and posted $60,000 bail. The alleged sexual assaults occurred on Feb. 21 and Feb. 28 of this year, according to a criminal complaint. A judge set a readiness conference for June 30 and trial was scheduled for Aug. 15. Two other men who worked at Mar Vista High,  Edward Aaron Mendoza  and  Martin Albert Gallegos , have also been charged in separate cases with having sex with students. Mendoza, a former football coach, is accused of having  a sexual relationship with a ninth-grade girl . Gallegos, a former ROTC instructor at Mar Vista, is accused of  having sex with a 12th-grade female student  on multiple occasions. City News Service (Image via Shutterstock)

Old Rape Case Closed A jury has convicted Herbert Leroy Holmes, 47, with a 1984 rape, and Holmes was sentenced to 30 years in jail,  according to Live 5 News .  Holmes was convicted of one count of first degree criminal sexual conduct and one count of kidnapping Thursday. The assault was on a Summerville bookstore employee, and Holmes was not charged with the case until 2009. Click here to read more . Pair Arrested for Meth Summerville Police have charged Victoria Kay Craver, 19, and Michael Cherry, 49, were charged with manufacturing methamphetamine after a traffic stop Friday,  according to ABC News 4 . A search of the vehicle showed materials consistent with manufacturing methamphetamine.  Click here to read more .  Woman Accused of Using Ambulance as Taxi Dorchester County Sheriff's Office has told media that Audrey Ferguson, 51, of Dorchester has called EMS and requested transport to Summerville Medical at least 100 times in seven years,  according to WISTV.com . Ferguson allegedly told deputies she didn't have a car and this was the only way she had to get around and Medicaid paid for it. Each ambulance trip cost $425 plus mileage.  Click here to read more .

Tigard police have arrested a suspect from the Key Bank robbery last month. The city's  Commercial Crimes Unit  investigators, with help from U.S. Marshals, arrested Kevin J. Castle at a Gresham-area apartment Mar. 14. Castle, 26, was reportedly taken into custody without incident.  According to Tigard police spokesman Jim Wolf, a Washington County Grand Jury indicted Castle Mar. 10 for allegedly robbing an "undisclosed amount of money" from the Tigard Key Bank at 11665 S.W. Pacific Highway after handing a bank employee a demand note Feb. 27. Castle implied he had a weapon, though no one was hurt before he fled the bank, police said.  Castle, who has no known address and a history of arrests in the Washington County area, is charged with second-degree robbery ( a Measure 11 crime ) and first-degree theft. He is currently being held at the Washington County Jail on Southwest Adams Avenue in Hillsboro. Photo Courtesy: Tigard Police Department

A 26-year-old Parsippany man has been charged with burglarizing the local Wendy's by smashing the drive-through window with a concrete block, police said. Quincy Penn allegedly burglarized the Wendy's at 2099 Route 46 around 3:3:0 a.m. on June 19.  Parsippany officers responded to the restaurant after the burglar alarm was activated. When officers arrived, they saw the shattered window and concrete block, and said the suspect forced entry into the locked office.  No word on what, if anything, was stolen. Penn was arrested and charged with burglary in the 3rd degree and criminal mischief. He was remanded to the Morris County Correctional Facility pending his court appearance. The Denville Police Department's Detective Bureau assisted with the investigation.

Quick police work on Thursday and the unique quality of an armed robbery suspect's voice helped officers track down two alleged robbers within minutes of the crime. The attempted robbery went down around 10:30 p.m. behind Menchie's, a frozen yogurt shop located in the Belle Hall Shopping Center, according to a police incident report. A teenage worker at the shop was taking out trash for the evening when he was apparently attacked from behind, the report states. The victim told officers one man put him in a choke hold and held a knife to his neck as a second suspect approached. Though the alleged victim couldn't provide a physical description of the suspects, he told officers that one of the robbers sounded like DeVaughn Unique Green, an employee fired from the yogurt shop just a few days before the robbery. The suspects fled the scene, and no money was taken. The victim said he thought the men were trying to enter the business to commit a robbery. Officers began patrolling the area and soon heard someone running through the woods near Seacoast Church. They arrested one suspect, Luke Carpenter, 19, on armed robbery charges. He was covered in grass and was breathing heavily the report states. Officers later spotted a woman leaving Carpenter's home. She said she was headed to pick up Carpenter and another man named DeVaughn. She said Carpenter had called, breathing heavily, needing a ride home. Officers don't say in their initial reports how they tracked down DeVaughn Green, 19, but arrest records show the teenage suspect was arrested with Carpenter and charged with armed robbery. Follow  Mount Pleasant Patch on Facebook  and  subscribe to our free daily and breaking news newsletter  for the latest local news.

pushing doctor in Monroe, NY adds a new dimension to the case of a wide-ranging Hudson Valley opiod drug ring. The case blew open after a teacher died in 2015 from an overdose of oxycodone and alprazolam, and authorities alleged his death was connected with an operation run by a doctor who wrote thousands of medically unnecessary and phony prescriptions for painkillers, and a confederate who sold them. "Unscrupulous healthcare professionals like Doctor Alfred Ramirez, who is alleged to have prescribed over 10,000 medically unnecessary oxycodone pills over a four-year period, and his alleged distributor, James Cooney, fuel this epidemic of poison by prescription," said U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara in 2015. The teacher was a Yonkers resident, as was the accused seller. The accused doc, a psychiatrist with a practice in Orange and Dutchess counties. The long list of investigating law enforcement agencies included the Westchester County Police Department, the Town of Orangetown Police Department, the Town of Woodbury Police Department and the Westchester County Department of Public Safety. Oxycodone is a prescription-strength Schedule II narcotic used to treat severe and chronic pain conditions. Oxycodone can result in addiction similar to an addiction to codeine or morphine, and there is a massive illegal market for oxycodone. Heroin has become a cheaper substitute. Ramirez had pleaded not guilty to the federal drug and conspiracy charges  and had been on house arrest awaiting trial. He was 78. Police went to his house when his ankle bracelet stopped transmitting information, the  Times Herald Record reported.  No foul play was suspected.

A racial profiling complaint has led to the arrest of the Storrs woman who made the accusation against a Connecticut State Trooper. According to a statement issued by state police, a trooper conducted a motor vehicle stop on Route 5/15 in Wethersfield on May 9. As a result of the motor vehicle stop, the operator was issued an infraction for Unsafe Lane Change.  Following the incident, the driver wrote a complaint letter to the Commissioner of the Department of Emergency Services and Public Protection (DESPP) alleging she was stopped and issued the infraction based upon the illegal practice of racial profiling. To sign up for breaking Mansfield and Storrs news alerts and more, click here.  The Connecticut State Police Internal Affairs office investigated the allegations against the trooper and concluded that statements provided by the accused were false and the Trooper was exonerated on all charges.  Based upon the nature of the complaint, a criminal investigation was initiated into the operator's allegations and an arrest warrant was applied for and granted by the Hartford Superior Court. At about 10:15 a.m. Tuesday, the driver, identified as Minati Roychoudhuri, of Fieldstone Drive, Storrs, surrendered at Troop H-Hartford on an arrest warrant charging her with second-degree false statement.  Roychoudhuri was released after posting $1,000 bond. She is scheduled to appear Aug 14 in state Superior Court in Hartford.

The owner of a Mission Viejo massage business was arrested on suspicion of sexually assaulting a female customer, and investigators believe there are additional alleged victims, a sheriff's lieutenant said Friday. Qing Dai, 40, of Mission Viejo, who owns Sunny's Massage at 24000 Alicia Parkway, No. 32, was taken into custody Thursday and booked on suspicion of one count of sexual battery, according to Orange County sheriff's Lt. Lane Lagaret. Prosecutors have received evidence related to three more alleged victims, so Dai could face further charges, he said. A 37-year-old woman came forward to sheriff's deputies on May 16, claiming she was sexually assaulted at the business, Lagaret said. On June 15, a 32-year-old woman made the same allegation, he said. Two other female customers previously alleged they were assaulted at the business, Lagaret said, but he did not have dates of those alleged incidents. Dai posted bail Thursday and was released, according to jail records. Investigators suspect there may be more alleged victims and encouraged anyone with information to call deputies at (714) 647-7419 or (714) 647-7000. Orange County Crime Stoppers will accept anonymous tips at (855) TIP-OCCS. Photo courtesy of the orange County Sheriff's Department

In the second anti-Muslim attack reported in New York City on Wednesday, Sept. 13, an unidentified suspect (pictured above) made "anti-Muslim remarks" to a 53-year-old man near the Dekalb Avenue L train station, then "slapped the victim's cellphone from his hand" and "punched him one time to the left side of his neck," according to the NYPD. The attack was carried out in broad daylight, around 8:30 a.m., police said, on the busy corner of  Wyckoff Avenue and Stockholm Street . Just a few hours later, at another subway stop in Forest Hills, Queens, a pair of Orthodox Jewish women were  brutally beaten  by a man who mistook them for Muslims and told them to go back to their "f---ing country," according to the Queens District Attorney. Dimitrios Zias, 40, was arrested soon after. ("Is it because I'm rich and white?" he allegedly told his arresting officers.) A total of 214 hate crimes were reported across NYC during the first six months of 2017, police data  shows . Of those, 25 were anti-Muslim or anti-Arab. An NYPD spokeswoman could not provide any details on what kind of anti-Muslim comments, exactly, were made in the Bushwick assault. Cops have yet to arrest anyone for the early-morning attack. However, this is the guy they're looking for: Police described the suspect as "a male with long hair and last seen wearing sandals with white socks and a black 'True Religion' t-shirt." Recognize him? You can tell police what you know  online  or via the NYPD tip line, at 1-800-577-8477. Photo courtesy of the NYPD

A 19-year-old Powder Springs woman has been arrested in connection with the stabbing of her 51-year-old stepfather. About 7:30 p.m. Sunday, Vince Anderson was walking along Powder Springs Road near Ponderosa Lane trying to flag down traffic. "Officers arrived to find the male ... bloody as a result of several stab wounds in the areas of his left arm, head and back," said Maj. Matt Boyd with the Powder Springs Police Department. Anderson told officers that his stepdaughter, Shaquioa Crawford, stabbed him during a domestic dispute at a residence in the 3700 block of Powder Springs Road, Boyd said. According to a Cobb County criminal warrant, they argued over the location of an EBT card. "The accused stated the victim grabbed her by the arm and tried to remove her from the residence," a Powder Springs police officer wrote in the warrant. "The accused admitted to removing a silver in color folding pocket knife from her pocket and striking the victim on the head and neck area causing cuts and lacerations to the victims head and neck." Crawford allegedly stabbed Anderson some more in the front yard. "The accused admitted to cutting the victim on the left arm area with the silver folding pocket knife," the officer wrote in the warrant. "The accused stated the victim then walked off and the accused returned to the residence." Anderson was taken to WellStar Cobb Hospital with two puncture wounds to the left arm and one puncture wound to the back of his head. Boyd said this evening that Anderson has been released from the hospital. Crawford was arrested on a charge of aggravated assault. She is being held at the Cobb County Adult Detention Center in lieu of $20,000 bond. "Powder Springs detectives are still investigating this case," Boyd said.

A 37-year-old former Woodstock man has been sentenced to nine years in prison for touching a 13-year-old child inappropriately, prosecutors said. Andres S. Gamez pleaded guilty to criminal sexual assault this past week and will serve his nine-year prison sentence concurrently to a seven-year sentence he received in Wisconsin for a similar charge. Gamez is accused of sexually assaulting the teen between May 21, 2015, and Jan. 31, 2015.  Authorities arrested Gamez on May 13, 2015, after officials at a Crystal Lake school notified police regarding the sexual assault allegations, according to the Northwest Herald. Gamez's wife was also arrested shortly after for allegations she harassed the teenage victim.  More via the Northwest Herald PHOTO VIA THE MCHENRY COUNTY STATE'S ATTORNEY'S OFFICE

A man accused of exposing himself to a woman as she was waking in the La Quinta Cove area has been arrested on suspicion of indecent exposure, sheriff's officials said Wednesday. The alleged lewd encounter happened around 8:30 a.m. Tuesday in the 77500 block of Calle Tecate, accordign to sheriff's Sgt. Robert Bishop. "The reporting person said she was walking in the area when a subject in a vehicle pulled up next to her and lewdly exposed himself," Bishop said in a news release.  The woman, whose name was not released, immediately reported the incident to police and was able to provide descriptions of the suspect and vehicle and the license plate number, Bishop said. Police tracked down Arthur Dean, 35, of La Quinta, at his house and arrested him, according to the sergeant. Dean was arrested Tuesday at his home and booked into the Riverside County jail in Indio on suspicion of misdemeanor indecent exposure, and was released after posting $2,500 bail, according to county jail records. — City News Service contributed to this report / Image via Riverside County Sheriff's Department

Two suspects were arrested by Acton Police on May 25 after allegedly attempting to break in to two local business, Acton Police Deputy Chief Richard Burrows announced Tuesday.  Police arrested Joshua P. Bucens, 19, of Boxborough on charges of breaking and entering in the night time to commit a felony, destruction of property over $250, attempting to commit a crime and possession of a burglarious instruments. Deokhoon Kim, 19, of Newton was arrested on the same charges, except for the possession of burglarious instruments. According to Burrows' announcement, witnesses told police that people were kicking and shouldering the rear door of Red White and Brew on Massachusetts Avenue, attempting to gain entry into the building. A witness took photos of the suspects entering a dark grey SUV and driving off, according to the announcement.  Burrows reports that after about an hour and a half, the alarm at Buscemi's Convenience Store was activated, and officers found the front door of the store smashed at the bottom. An officer observed an SUV that matched the description, and arrested the two occupants in the vehicle after conducting an investigation, according to Burrows' announcement.

A Beechview man was shot and killed Sunday afternoon in the East Carnegie neighborhood that straddles Pittsburgh, Scott Township and Green Tree. Mileek Grissom, 23, was pronounced dead at 3:44 p.m. at Mercy Hospital not long after the shooting in the 600 block of Noblestown Road, according to the Allegheny County medical examiner's office. An autopsy is scheduled for Monday morning. The  Pittsburgh Post-Gazette  reported that investigators charged 24-year-old Lamar Alston with criminal homicide, aggravated assault, evidence tampering, fleeing police and criminal attempt. He apparently left the scene and was stopped by a and his dog. Heidelberg police Chief Vernon Barkley said Sgt. Dennis Dixon and his German shepherd, Rocky, responded to the shooting scene to assist other officers. Rocky "tracked and apprehended" the suspect by biting him when he refused to listen to orders from police officers to put down his gun, Barkley said. He added that the suspect was taken to Allegheny County Jail. "This is what all the training and mutual aid is about," Barkley said. Officers from Collier, Scott, Green Tree and Carnegie also assisted Pittsburgh police in arresting the homicide suspect. Pittsburgh police are handling the investigation because it happened in their jurisdiction. Like the  Chartiers Valley Patch Facebook page  or sign up for our  Daily E-mail Newsletter

Two men face several charges after being uncooperative during a DWI arrest, with one of the men accused of spitting on police officers, Washington Township police said.  Donald Phillips, 41, of Hickory, North Carolina, and Daniel Davinci, 32, of Hackettstown, both face several charges stemming from an early-morning incident on Dec. 31. Police say the men were stopped in front of the Schooleys Mountain Fire House with a flat fire around 1 a.m. when police found them. Phillips, who police say was driving, allegedly smelled like alcohol and refused to answer any questions. Police asked him to complete field sobriety tests, and he allegedly refused. He was placed under arrest and taken to police headquarters. Davinci, the passenger, was also arrested for an active warrant. Police say he spit "all over" the inside of the police car while being taken to headquarters, and continued to spit at officers during processing. Davinci is accused of kicking the inside of the patrol car doors while being transferred to the Morris County Correctional Facility to be picked up by Monmouth County authorities; police say they placed him in leg restraints. Phillips was charged with DWI, refusal to provide breath samples and reckless driving. Davinci was charged with criminal mischief and resisting arrest.  Image via Shutterstock

Hoboken police arrested a local man after he allegedly cut himself and generated a false police report, then blamed the incident on a "misidentified person," authorities say. According to the Hoboken Police Department, officers originally responded to the scene of an alleged stabbing near Third and Monroe streets around 10:50 a.m. on Aug. 22. On arrival, the officers found a man walking in the area with what appeared to be slash wounds to his left triceps and rib area. The man gave a formal statement that identified his alleged assailant, which eventually led officers to issue an arrest warrant for the accused person, authorities said. There was just one problem, according to police; the information was "false." Hoboken police had this to say about the incident: On Thursday, police arrested the man who gave the false report, Robert Negron-Soto, 52, of Hoboken, and charged him with providing a false report to law enforcement authorities, a fourth-degree crime. "Negron-Soto cooperated with detectives and provided a full statement confirming that he provided false information implicating an innocent person," Hoboken police stated. "Negron-Soto went on to say that the wounds were self-inflicted and he did so because of personal reasons." Keep updated with local public safety alerts at the Patch Hoboken Facebook page. Send local news tips and correction requests to eric.kiefer@patch.com

They got him: Austin police this week announced the arrest of a suspect in connection with a pair of recent home invasion robberies.  Member of the Region 3 Metro Tactical Unit arrested David Cardenas, 22, for a home invasion robbery that occurred on May 22 along the 700 block of Longspur Boulevard. Police said Cardenas also was charged with a subsequent home invasion on May 24 along the 1500 block of West Braker Lane.  In the earlier home invasion, Cardenas is accused of kicking in the door of an apartment while its occupants were sleeping inside. A woman inside the apartment was awakened by the home invasion before Cardenas allegedly threatened her while demanding valuables and then fleeing the scene. The woman and other occupants were uninjured, police said.  In their search for the suspect, the Austin Police Department previously released surveillance camera footage showing Cardenas approaching the apartment unit before scurrying off.

An alleged laundry room thief had a dirty trick up his sleeve, according to a police report. At approximately 11:30 p.m. July 25, a tenant in the notified police that someone was breaking into the machines in the communal laundry room. When an officer responded to the complex and opened the door, he found a man sitting on the laundry room floor with the dryer upside down between his legs. He appeared to be working on the machine, the report stated. Police ordered the man to the ground, placed him in handcuffs and found a small tool in his pocket. When asked what he was doing, the suspect said, "Someone showed me how to get the coins out of the machine. You know times are tough right now," police said. The suspect had several warrants out for his arrest, including one for an undisclosed crime in Chesterfield Township. There were also several reports of stolen coins from the Aspen Creek laundry room before this incident. For questions about this blotter, email  christy.arboscello@patch.com .

degree sexual abuse for allegedly sexually abusing a young woman while threatening her with a hand saw and burning her with cigarettes. Nathan L. Justice, 17, was charged following an incident in Fairfax. He is accused of committing a sex act by force against the will of an 18-year-old woman, according to a  criminal complaint viewed by KCRG . The Linn County sheriff's office said the woman told investigators Justice threatened her with a hand saw while he performed a sex act on her at a residence in Fairfax. Justice also allegedly burned the woman several times with a cigarette butt. Col. John Stuelke told the station that the incident was reported to the sheriff's office on Nov. 13, and Justice was arrested Nov. 16 at his residence. Stuelke would not say if there were any witnesses to the incident, and declined to comment on other specifics of the case. According to a criminal complaint, investigators recovered the saw and cigarette butt allegedly used during the incident. Justice previously was convicted in juvenile court of third-degree sexual abuse after an incident with a 13-year-old girl on Jan. 1, 2011, KCRG reported. He spent seven months at the State Training School for Boys in Eldora before he was released to the custody of his father in Des Moines in March, according to court records. Justice has a history of substance abuse and runaway behaviors, the station reported.  He was being held at the Linn County Juvenile Detention Center. Bond has been set at $75,000.

The suspect in a deadly shooting in  Cedar Park earlier this month is said to have confessed to the crime on Facebook, according to published reports.  Referencing an arrest affidavit, Jose Loza, 26, is accused of fatally shooting Fernando Lopez, 22, as the victim and his uncle sat in a car at the corner of 183A and East Whitestone Boulevard at around 6 a.m., CBS Austin reported. The older man was hospitalized for medical treatment of gunshot wounds.  Prior to the killing, according to the report, Lopez feared for his life after multiple threats from the suspect. The reason for Loza's ire was that Lopez had texted the suspect's ex-girlfriend, according to the report. The suspect is said to have expressed his anger on Facebook: "It was me, I called him, I killed him," and "I don't give a f***, I have the b****," Loza is said to have written. Loza fled the city after the shooting before being taken into custody in Houston.  Related story:  Arrest Made In Fatal Cedar Park Shooting >>>  Read the full story at CBS Austin

first as an actual employee, then as an impostor. Police say that 28-year-old Aaron Alexander Holmes was fired from the Burnsville Walmart in mid-March. Nevertheless, on April 28 he allegedly donned the standard Walmart uniform—a blue shirt and khaki pants, complete with name tag—and headed to the store. Once inside, he approached an employee who was "very busy" and tricked them into giving him a walkie-talkie and a set of keys. Holmes quickly made off with three Apple iPads, collectively valued at $1,697. The next day, Holmes appeared at the store again and took three more iPads while an accomplice distracted the staff. On his way out, he was confronted by Walmart employees, but managed to get away before police arrived. Store management positively identified the suspect seen on surveillance as Holmes. According to the criminal complaint, the six stolen iPads are just the tip of the iceberg. A search of pawn store records revealed that Holmes sold 56 high value electronic items from Nov. 3, 2012 through April 24, 2013. The total retail value of the pawned items and the six missing tops $20,000. Holmes has been charged with receiving stolen property, a felony with a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and a $20,000 fine. He remains in custody at the Dakota County Jail, held on a $30,000 bond. The bond will be reduced to $15,000 if Holmes agrees to abide by the court's conditions, among them: Stay away from the Walmart.  His next court appearance is scheduled for June 4.
